name: Care and Use of Animals for Scientific Purposes
description: The application process for using animals for scientific or educational purposes in Western Australia, integrating the Animal Welfare Act 2002, the Biodiversity Conservation Act 2016, and the Australian Code for the Care and Use of Animals for Scientific Purposes. It is designed to guide applicants, investigators, Animal Ethics Committee (AEC) members, and other stakeholders through the process.

steps.title: Scientific Review

sections.title: Endorsement

questions.label: I endorse this application and confirm the scientific merit of the project.

sections.description: I have reviewed this application and assessed the scientific merit of the project. I confirm that proposed aims, design, methodology, and analyses are scientifically rigorous and will adequately inform the research question being posed. Advice has been sought from a consulting/reviewing scientist where necessary.

sections.title: Scientific Integrity

questions.label: I have read and understood the scientific integrity agreement.

sections.description:
Respect for animals must underpin all decisions and actions involving the care and use of animals for scientific purposes. Applying high standards of scientific integrity is one of the governing principles outlined in the Australian Code for the Care and Use of Animals for Scientific Purposes - 8th Edition (the Code). Each person involved in the care and use of animals for scientific purposes must consider the governing principles when applying the Code to their specific circumstance.

The below clauses from the Code contribute to the ethical framework that guides decisions and actions of all people involved in the care and use of animals for scientific purposes.

1.15 Regardless of the potential benefits of a project, the methods used must be scientifically valid, feasible, well designed and carefully conducted so that there is a reasonable expectation that the aims of the project will be achieved. Projects that are not scientifically valid must not be performed, no matter how mild the impact on the wellbeing of the animals.

1.16 Investigators must use methods that accord with current best practice that:
	i. take into consideration relevant aspects of species-specific biology, physiology and behaviour
	ii. are based on the best available scientific evidence, which includes the potential adverse impact of conditions and procedures on the wellbeing of the animals
	iii. include strategies to minimise adverse impacts.

1.17 Animals used must be suited to the purpose of the project or activity, taking into account their biological characteristics, including morphology, physiology, behaviour, genetic makeup, temperament and behavioural conditioning, microbiological and nutritional status, and general state of health.

Chief Investigators are encouraged to engage with a relevant scientist or biometrician during the project planning phase to ensure projects are scientifically valid, feasible, and well designed. For information on where to obtain scientific advice/assistance to aid in the review process, visit the Animal Ethics Committee intranet or contact the Executive Officer.

steps.description: Submit your project for scientific review.

steps.title: Terms of Service

sections.title: User Agreement

questions.label: I have read and understood the terms of service.

sections.description: Please answer all sections thoroughly and in plain English and ensure all acronyms are defined the first time they are used. The information provided in this application should support the case for ethical acceptability of the project and allow the AEC to assess the project in relation to requirements of the Code.

sections.title: Death as an endpoint

questions.label: This project does NOT involve death as an endpoint.

sections.description: If your project involves death of an animal as a deliberate measure used for evaluating biological or chemical processes, responses or effects please contact the AEC Executive Officer. You will be required to fill out a different form.

steps.description: Read and accept the terms of service.

sections.title: Chief Investigator (CI) Declaration

questions.label: I acknowledge that as CI, I have ultimate responsibility for the care and use of animals in this project and agree to the above conditions and requirements.

I acknowledge that as CI, I have advised all project personnel that they must have read, understood and accepted their responsibilities in accordance with the Code, and are aware of their role and responsibility as part of this project.

sections.description:
a) The Code:  
	• I have read, understood and agree to abide by the Australian Code for the Care and Use of Animals for Scientific Purposes 8th Edition; including Chapter 2.4: Responsibilities of investigators.
b) Project personnel responsibilities:  
	• I will ensure that all project personnel are aware of and understand the techniques, methodology and any conditions approved for this project and any relevant Department Standard Operating Procedures.
	• Personnel identified as competent animal handlers have the qualifications, experience and training required for all procedures and species identified for the project, and have the competency to deal with adverse events should they occur.  
	• Supervised training by a competent and trained person will be provided for all personnel that do not have the required level of skill and experience.  
c) Project resources (funding & personnel):
	• Adequate resources will be available to ensure that the project is conducted according to the project approval and conditions and animal welfare is not compromised.
d) Adverse events:
	• I agree to notify the AEC of any significant issues relating to this project and to submit an Adverse Event form for any unexpected deaths or injuries at the earliest possible opportunity.
e) Documentation and reporting:
	• I will keep records of the qualifications and / or experience of all listed personnel. 
	• I agree to submit annual reports by the due date and to the standard required by the AEC.
	• I agree to maintain all documentation associated with this project as required under the Code and the Departmental policy on record-keeping.

I acknowledge that all the information contained in the application form is a true and accurate record.

As per Section 2.4.5 of the Code:

sections.title: Benefits of Project

questions.label: Purpose of the proposed project
Key aims / objectives
Explain the relevance, benefits and the justification for the project
questions.description: Applicants must demonstrate that the benefits of undertaking the project are justified in relation to the potential impact on animals, e.g How will your project contribute to the conservation of wildlife? How will it improve knowledge and understanding of biodiversity, ecosystems and processes?

sections.description: Identify the benefits of the project outcomes and evidence that supports the use of animals.

steps.description: Fill in the details of your project.

steps.title: Study Design & Methodology

sections.title: Overall Design

questions.label: Project design description
questions.description: i.e. site locations, number of sites, trap types, numbers of traps, spacing/configuration, frequency and timing of monitoring.

questions.label: Species and number of individuals that will be handled or observed
questions.description: Please use current taxonomy from the NOMOS - taxonomic names management system.

grid_columns.label: Total animals
grid_columns.description: Total number of animals to be handled (or observed) during the project time frame as indicated in Q7.

sections.description:
Please provide a description of the overall project design, methodology and sampling times.

Example: 
•	This project will use a 20km transect of 50 small baited cage traps, at 200m intervals, to target medium-sized mammals. 
•	The project will also use a grid of 16 pitfall traps, 8 funnel traps, and 8 Elliott traps to target small mammals, reptiles and amphibians. The grid will have four lines of four pitfall buckets with two funnel traps per line, and one Elliott trap at each end of the four pitfall lines.  
•	The project involves trapping at three sites, which will be monitored once per year for each site, and traps will be run for four consecutive nights.
•	It is anticipated that it will take project personnel approximately xx hours to complete trap checking and processing of captures.

steps.description: Project design, methodology and sampling times.

steps.title: Replacement, Reduction & Refinement

sections.title: Replacement of Methods / Techniques / Equipment

questions.label: Alternative LESS INVASIVE OR LOWER IMPACT TECHNIQUES, that would provide comparable data to answer the objectives of this project, ARE AVAILABLE.

The handling or observation of animals in their natural environment is necessary to achieve the objective(s) of this project.  I have investigated and considered alternative options in relation to methods, techniques and equipment that minimise the risk to animal welfare (including disease and direct and indirect disturbance to the habitat).  I have identified that there are no suitable or more appropriate alternatives to achieve the objectives of this project.
Why the available methods are not suitable?
questions.description: Less invasive/lower impact methods are available - please identify the techniques and explain why they are not suitable for the project.

sections.description:
Refer Clauses 1.18, 1.19, 1.20 

Methods that replace or partially replace the use of animals must be investigated, considered and, where applicable, implemented to minimise welfare impacts. (Refer clauses 1.18, 1.19, 1.20). 

Section 3.3 (3.3.33-3.3.44) Wildlife and field techniques

The wellbeing of wildlife must be supported and safeguarded by using methods, techniques and equipment that are appropriate and avoid or minimise harm including pain and distress to target and non-target species.

sections.title: Reduction of Numbers and/or Effort

questions.label: Explain the necessity for the number of animals to be handled.
questions.description: Explain how the number of animals to be handled or observed and/or the sampling effort supports the validity of the research. e.g. statistical rigour, training, education. Consider whether the length (number of continuous days’ trapping) and number of survey sessions is appropriate to achieve the outcomes of your project while also minimising the impact on animals.

sections.description:
Refer clauses 1.21 to 1.27 

Minimise the number of animals used while ensuring good statistical and experimental design.

Section 3.3 (3.3.33-3.3.44) Wildlife and field techniques.

sections.title: Refinement of Techniques

questions.label: Method of capture / observation
questions.description: Selecting methods that are appropriate to the species & circumstances; avoiding or minimising harm to target and non-target species.

questions.label: Timing and frequency of trap checking
questions.description: Identify the timing and frequency of trap checking and provide justification where these differ from the SOPs.

questions.label: Other methods
questions.description: Including VHF/GPS/Satellite collars or tags; Vouchering

questions.label: Transmitter specifications
questions.description: Type, weight, minimum battery life, release mechanism

questions.label: Transmitters length of time
questions.description: Length of time transmitters will be left on or checked for replacement.

questions.label: Re-trapping
questions.description: Explain how animals will be re-trapped to check, replace or remove transmitters.

questions.label: Method of marking / sampling

grid_columns.label: Species and number of animals to be marked
grid_columns.description: You can refer to the Species Table if all the information is contained in the Table.

questions.label: Detail surgical invasive procedures to be carried out on animals (if applicable)
Describe pain management plans for surgery (if applicable)
Further measures
questions.description: Identify any further measures that will refine your methods to improve animal welfare outcomes.

questions.label: Animal handling timeline
questions.description: Brief description and expected timeline from start to finish for animal handling. e.g. animals will be removed from trap, morphometrics taken and released at point of capture. On average handling time will be no more than 5 minutes per individual.

questions.label: Describe transport and/or housing of animals (if applicable)

sections.description:
Refer Clauses 1.28, 1.29, 1.30 

Steps must be taken at all times to support and safeguard animal wellbeing. Section 3.3 (3.3.33-3.3.44) Wildlife and field techniques.

steps.description: Minimise the welfare impact on animals.

sections.title: Adverse events

questions.label: Identify key strategies and measures to assess, monitor and manage animal wellbeing, including expected and unexpected adverse events.
questions.description: This section should explain how you will monitor animal welfare and manage impacts including signs of elevated stress, ejected pouch young and unexpected injuries. Include details, where appropriate, on the decision-making steps that project personnel will take regarding adverse events. Include your Euthanasia Plan: briefly outline the decision-making process for determining when an animal should be humanely killed, and any arrangements for euthanasia and/or post mortem examination.

questions.label: Pest species
questions.description: If pest species (e.g. wild dog, fox, cat, rabbit, black rat, house house) are target or potential non-target species, please identify how you intend to manage these species (eg release at point of capture, euthanase).

questions.label: Expected adverse events
questions.description: If you expect to have some adverse events (e.g. predation events, pouch young deaths), please try to provide an estimate of the likely numbers for each type of event.

sections.description: Unexpected adverse event: an event that may have a negative impact on the wellbeing of animals and was not foreshadowed in the approved project or activity.

sections.title: Humane Killing (Euthanasia)

questions.label: Methods for euthanasia
questions.description: Identify method(s) in table below. If the method is species specific, please use the last (blank) column to identify the species, group of species etc to which this method will be applied.

questions.label: Identify the criteria that project personnel will use to confirm death
Additional information (please include firearms licence # if appropriate)

sections.description:
Euthanasia: the method and procedures for euthanasia must be humane and appropriate to the species and circumstances.

Section 3.3 (3.3.45-3.3.46) Humane killing

The methods and procedures must produce rapid loss of consciousness until death, be appropriate to the species, age, developmental stage and health of the animal, be reliable, be done in an environment away from other animals, ensure that death is established before disposal of the carcass.

questions.label: Any additional information in relation to euthanasia and/or adverse events

steps.title: Substances

questions.label: List ANY administered substances, including sedatives, vitamin injections and substances to be used
Please complete all calculations for all injectables

steps.description: Including sedatives, vitamin injections, drugs or poisons.

questions.label: List of provisions

sections.description: Describe provisions that will be made for the animals at the conclusion of fieldwork/experiment?
